PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8 (2), 8 (15) and (11)) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators McGauran (from 14 citizens) and Puplick (from three citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mining exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park; and

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate:

The undersigned citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth oppose the patenting of animals and the process for altering them. Animal patents would reduce biodiversity, compromise animal welfare, concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more;
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam War from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the fact that it now takes 40 weeks of average earnings to buy an Australian car, compared to 33 weeks of average earnings in 1985, an accurate reflection of the extent of your failure in your portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that Question Time was a vehicle for eliciting information. This question was put to me last night by Senator Chapman during an Estimates committee hearing. We will run through it again, if that is what Senator Chapman wants. There has been some outdated reporting on what has been happening to the prices of cars. The Government is well aware that the track record of the industry on price has not been as good as it could have been. The Government is aware of that, as is everybody in the community, because the Automotive Industry Authority publishes an annual report in which it comments on car prices, quality issues and a whole range of issues which affect the motor vehicle industry and its performance. Those comments in the annual report have not always been received with great favour by the motor vehicle industry. It has not always been entirely happy about them, but I regard it as proper for a government body which has something to do with the administration of a highly protected industry to say those things.

ANSWER.PARA: Since substantial tariff cuts were introduced in mid-1988 there have, however, been some good improvements on past performances which were influenced by unfavourable currency movements. For example, with the 1985-86 devaluation of the Australian dollar, car prices in Australia rose significantly. Whether the price of manufactured vehicles should or should not have followed up the price of imported vehicles which followed from that devaluation is a debatable point. That is a perfectly good question and a legitimate debating point.

But price trends over the last few years will show overall that the industry has lifted its game and that often apparent price increases reflect changed specifications and upgrades of motor vehicles, both here and in other countries, demanded by an increasingly sophisticated motoring public. Motor vehicles which are manufactured here and imported today are technologically much more sophisticated then they were a few years ago. That is reflected in price.

Last week, the Automotive Industry Authority reported that price increases had moderated substantially and, for the past two years, both imported and locally made car prices increased at rates below the consumer price index. Price increases in the March 1990 quarter represent the eighth successive quarter during which car prices have been below the CPI. My answer to the question relating to average weekly earnings is yes if that figure is spaced over a period of years. Sure, there were significant increases in car prices following the devaluation of the Australian dollar and there have been increases in car prices, both here and elsewhere, as a result of the more sophisticated specifications required by consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has seen reports of a review of the Royal Mint in the United Kingdom by the Auditor-General which shows that the 1p and 2p coins cost more to make than their face value. Is the Minister also aware that New Zealand, as part of its micro-economic reform, is scrapping its 1c and 2c coins, which have not been legal tender since 30 April and will be melted down for scrap metal? Has the position in regard to the $29m worth of 1c coins and $46m worth of 2c coins issued in Australia been reviewed recently, and was the cost of production of the 135 million 1c pieces and 28 million 2c pieces produced last financial year greater than their face value?

—I am aware of the United Kingdom report. With regard to New Zealand, I saw the press reports that from 30 April those coins are no longer legal tender and will be melted down for scrap metal. At this stage the Australian Government has not made any decision to withdraw the 1c and 2c coins. However, the adequacy of the Australian coinage system is something which is continually under review by the Government. It is not appropriate that I comment on the cost of production at the Royal Australian Mint. These figures need to be treated as commercially confidential in view of the fact that the Mint is in competition with overseas mints in export markets.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEXTILE, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRIES: PROTECTION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Yesterday, the Treasurer indicated that he had an ambitious program for further reductions in protection in your portfolio and stated that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we still have plenty of scope for substantial reductions in tariffs and I want to see that accomplished in the immediate period . . .

Will the planned mid-term review of the assistance arrangements for the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries be brought forward, will the review examine the issues of accelerated reductions in protection, and has the Treasurer discussed with you the Treasurer's agenda for further accelerated reductions in protection for the TCF industries prior to the expiry of the current arrangements in 1995?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see that the Treasurer said that he had an ambitious program for micro-economic reform. One way or another it was drawn to my attention. Let me say that in terms of the mid-term review of the textile, clothing and footwear plan and whether that should be brought forward, the Government has made no decision about that matter. In regard to the question about an accelerated reduction in protection for the textile, clothing and footwear industries, the answer as to whether the Treasurer has discussed that question with me-I am not sure whether he has said anything in public-is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. At the recent Forty-sixth Session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights the Australian Government made a statement regarding its concern over serious abuses of human rights in Iran. What follow-up action does the Government intend to take over the general level of persecution of political and religious minorities in Iran? Is the Minister aware of media reports whereby Iranian exiles have accused the Iranian Government of directing a campaign of terrorism and assassinations abroad? Is the Government concerned about the assassination on Swiss soil of Dr Kazem Rajavi, a former Iranian ambassador to Switzerland and a leading opponent of the Tehran Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government remains concerned about the continuing allegations of human rights abuses in Iran, but we have been encouraged that at the United Nations General Assembly, Iran agreed that it would accept, for the first time, a visit by the Commission on Human Rights Special Representative in Iran. The visit by the Special Representative Professor Galindo Pohl took place in January, and the report of his visit was presented to the Forty-sixth Session of the Commission on Human Rights in February. Australia regards the visit of Galindo Pohl as an important step in advancing a productive dialogue on human rights matters between Iran and the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: We shall continue to monitor the situation in Iran closely and pay particular attention to Iran's adherence to commitments it made to improve human rights conditions in its discussions with Professor Galindo Pohl. Iran has also agreed to another visit this year by Professor Pohl and Australia will be closely monitoring the outcome of his visit.

Australia has made its concerns over human rights in Iran clearly known to the Iranian authorities on a number of occasions over the past year. In addition to our statements at the United Nations General Assembly and the Commission on Human Rights, Australia has approached the Iranian authorities over individual cases of alleged human rights abuse on five occasions in the past year. Australia's concerns include the treatment of minorities and religious groups such as members of the Baha'i faith. Australia will continue to urge the Iranian Government to adhere to internationally accepted standards of human rights.

I have seen reports that Dr Kazem Rajavi, the brother of the leader of the principal Iranian Opposition group, the Majahadin E Khalz, was killed by gunfire in Switzerland last month. The Government naturally condemns this act of terrorism and encourages Swiss and international efforts to apprehend those responsible. I am also aware that Iranians opposed to the Government in Tehran have accused that Government of responsibility for the murder and of waging an international terrorist campaign. The Australian Government does not have evidence linking the attack to the Iranian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and relates to the commitment made by the Labor Government on 7 March 1990 to nominate Shark Bay to the World Heritage List. What stage has been reached with the preparation of the nomination? When does the Minister plan to present the nomination to the World Heritage Committee? Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority is currently assessing a gypsum mine sited in an area of Shark Bay which is approved as a national park? Finally, is the Minister aware that gypsum mining has the potential to seriously damage the World Heritage values of Shark Bay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Jenkins has mentioned, I announced some time ago that Shark Bay would be nominated for the World Heritage List. I think at the time I indicated that that nomination would go forward this year, and that is still the Government's intention. The Minister, Mrs Kelly, will be having some discussions with her counterpart in Western Australia, Mr Pearce, next month, as I understand it, to attempt to finalise nomination. We need to finalise a boundary, there never having been an agreed one. I think that Mr Pearce's department and our own environment department are currently having discussions about what an appropriate boundary might be.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe that it is possible to rush that process because obviously we need to have concern for those who live in the area who are worried about the listing itself. There are not as many of them as there used to be, but there are still some people who are motivated largely by malice who spend a great deal of time attempting to stir things up. In that context I refer mainly to the Basic Industries Group in Western Australia-and extraordinary organisation which has pushed quite lovingly the League of Rights line about world government and all the rest of it. I worry about people like that and I am not certain that they represent their constituency. Nonetheless, they have been doing it, aided and abetted by some people in the Western Australian Liberal Party. Having said that, I point out that Mr Pearce in particular has spent quite a deal of time talking to people in the region and opposition has greatly diminished. However, we need to talk more to those people and ensure that a boundary can be finalised.
As far as mining goes, I think that Senator Jenkins and all honourable senators would be aware that the World Heritage convention does not prevent mining. The test for a gypsum mine--

TALK.START.PARA: —Only Senator Richardson stops that!
—Perish the thought, Senator Crichton-Browne! The only thing that stops mining is concern for the environment and then only on occasions.
—Except when you were on our committee.

—That is not true. You have misrepresented that position consistently for two years and continue to do so. But that is all right, Senator Crichton-Browne; you can do that if you like, because it keeps you over there and us over here.
—You're not really a greenie; you're a pragmatic politician.
—No, no! I have to disappoint you.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister answer the question.

—As I said, mining is not prevented specifically by the convention. That being the case, the test is whether the mine affects values. That is something that the Western Australian and Commonwealth governments will have to consider. But at this stage when we do not even have a boundary, it is very difficult to talk about whether we will approve anything, because there is quite some way to go yet.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Given that the West Australian Chip and Pulp Company Pty Ltd is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Bunnings Ltd, which has more than 80 per cent of the hardwood market in Western Australia, and that the need to fill WACAP's woodchip quota results in the logging of forest which, with higher sawn timber recovery, would not need to be logged because the State's sawn timber requirements could be met from two-thirds to one-half of the area now being logged, would the Minister immediately reduce by half the export quota of the West Australian Chip and Pulp Company Pty Ltd in order to stop the current inefficient and wasteful use of old grade karri logs and extend the time before the mature forest resource is completely exhausted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand from my reading that this question is based on a press report which appeared in the West Australian on Friday, 11 May. According to the newspaper, the report was prepared by Mr Alex Syme, of the Coalition for Denmark's Environment, and was released by the coalition, which includes the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Campaign to Save Native Forests, the Conservation Council of WA, and the South-West Forests Defence Association. That report makes the claims that Senator Vallentine has insinuated in her question.

ANSWER.PARA: I also am aware from the newspaper report that Bunnings, the company referred to in the question, has disagreed fundamentally with the propositions that have been put by Senator Vallentine, extrapolated from the report, and has invited environmental groups to two of its facilities. According to the newspaper report, Mr Bunning said that his company recovered about 90 per cent of the average log, including chips, charcoal and low grade timber products. A spokesman for the company said that it was mathematically impossible to recover 60 per cent of a log as sawn timber.

I do not want to enter into this contention about who is right exactly and who is wrong exactly other than to make the point that these reports are generated by people with a particular point of view in this debate and they ought not to be necessarily regarded as objective in terms of an analysis of the issues. The other point I need to make is that the forests in Western Australia are managed by the Western Australian Government, through its Department of Conservation and Land Management, on the principle of sustainable yield; that is to say, when the forests are logged, they regenerate; the rate at which they are logged determines what the yield is and not what a forestry company or a timber industry company may wish to claim.

Therefore, what determines the volume of cut is the rate of regeneration and the replacement of that forest. So from that point of view the implication that somehow there will be a complete loss of forest cover is an implication that ought not to be accepted automatically; that was indeed an implication in the question. Until the report from which these details are extrapolated is made available to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy-which until now has not been favoured with a copy of the report-I do not think I can add anything more to the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Now that the Minister has had time to reconsider the Australian Federal Police report on the recent arrest of a Thai national in Bangkok on drug charges, does the Minister still tell the Senate that there was nothing in the report that referred to the arrest or trial in Sydney of a relative of the Thai national, or the arrest or trial of any other persons claimed to be associates of the Thai national? Will the Minister now either table a copy of the Australian Federal Police report or, if it is operationally sensitive, make a copy of the report available to the shadow Attorney-General in accordance with the established convention?

—The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to the second part of the question is that I do not regard a convention as having been established in the way in which Senator Hill presumes and I do not intend to release the submission that was made to me concerning the arrest in Thailand.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of widespread concern in the areas bordering the Murray River about a proposal by the Albury City Council to discharge treated sewage effluent into the Murray? Is there any action that the Federal Government can take to prevent possible pollution of this important river and the land bordering it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the issue of Albury City Council's proposal to dump partly treated sewage into the Murray River. In fact, on 2 March, in my former incarnation as Minister for Resources, I put out a press statement asking the New South Wales Government's State Pollution Control Commission to deter the Albury City Council from so doing until such time as we had had a chance to study what other options there are for the disposal of this sewage. I am not-and as Minister for Resources was not-at all convinced that the simple expedient of dumping the sewage into the river is anything like responsible action by a local government authority. So, certainly, I am aware of the problem and I am aware of the outcry that emanated from downstream local government authorities and communities.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that the Albury City Council has proved uncooperative with government agencies in addressing this matter. It has failed to discuss the details of its proposal with the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, which is the responsible authority coordinating the activities of the Murray River States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and of the Commonwealth. It has not made known the amount of tonnes of partly treated sewage it proposes to dump into the river system. It has not consulted on the other options; as I have said, I am not convinced that there are no other options. I share the concern, and indeed outrage, of downstream communities about the effects for them on the quality of drinking water and irrigation water.

If a pipeline were run from the Lake Alexandrina outlet of the Murray back to Albury and the Albury City Council had to drink that water, maybe its view of its responsibility to the downstream communities would be greater.

Our concerns at a Federal level are real. For example, we know that the Albury City Council beat its breast that it has reduced the critically important nutrient of phosphorous in its treated sewage down to two milligrams per litre. It regards that as an achievement. That is hardly an achievement, because I can inform the Senate that the Canberra and Queanbeyan sewage treatment works' phosphorus level is 0.5 milligrams per litre-that is to say, 1.5 milligrams less than the Albury City Council claims is an achievement for it. That is just one chemical without reference to the other chemicals and heavy metals involved.

Under me as Minister for Resources in the previous Government and now under the present Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, we have undertaken a process of developing a water quality policy for the Murray-Darling basin. The Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council will deal with this matter at its next meeting, which I understand is in July, and I hope that we can see an end to some local government authorities and industrial enterprises treating the Murray as a dumping gutter and a recognition and respect for that river system as being vital to the economic and ecological well-being of the Riverland States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs assure the Senate that the failure of the prosecutions arising from Operation Seville is not a matter that requires independent investigation?

—The failure of the prosecutions in relation to the particular persons allegedly connected with the growing of certain marijuana crops was due to matters which the magistrate spoke about when the cases collapsed. I believe that the magistrate himself indicated that there was a difficulty with one of the indemnified witnesses who was not prepared to live up to the undertakings he had given when he was granted those indemnities. So I believe we already have on the record the assessment by the presiding judicial officer as to the reasons those particular prosecutions collapsed.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In your interview on Sunday on the Walsh Report, which Mr Keating used as the pretext for his scathing attack on your ministerial performance, the main points you made were that, in the current `economic downturn of some severity', it is unrealistic to talk about rising living standards; that the economic outlook for Australia over the next few years will be very difficult; and that opportunities for micro-economic reform in Labor's third term were lost and time has to be made up. Do you resile from or regret those comments in the light of Mr Keating's response?

—I do not resile from the comments made on the Walsh Report program. But yesterday, in respect of the third point which Senator Baume addressed to me today, I elaborated upon my answer in the Walsh Report, and I said that there were some areas of micro-economic reform in the last term of the Labor Government which we probably did not address as well as we might have. I mentioned at least one area of tariff reform, and I certainly mentioned the question of telecommunications because there was a wide range of reports coming to Government about various aspects of telecommunications technologies and so on which prevented us from dealing with that issue. In so far as the general tone of that discussion on the program to which Senator Michael Baume refers is concerned, I tabled the transcript of that interview in the Senate yesterday. It is my view that we will have some economic difficulties in the next 12 months. That is the burden of the interview; I do not resile from that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister: As the Treasurer denied at 2.20 p.m. today in Question Time in the House of Representatives that there currently is an economic downturn of some severity in Australia, does Senator Button persist in his view that there is one or will he now resile from that?
—I do not know what the Treasurer said at Question Time today. I know that he was reported in newspapers on Saturday as having a sombre view about the next few months. I share that view.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a media report which states that greater Sydney was sitting on an environmental time bomb of hospital residue which includes liquid toxic waste and human tissue? What is the Commonwealth Government's position regarding the dumping of such waste? Are there controls to stop States from dumping waste which may be environmentally dangerous and has the potential to spread infection? Has a royal commission been requested into the dumping of such waste?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I know that Mrs Kelly is aware of the report which I think came from a meeting convened by the State member for Londonderry-a Labor member, I might say-Mr Paul Gibson. He is most concerned at the possibility of a toxic waste dump close to the very large numbers of people who live in western Sydney, as well he might be.

ANSWER.PARA: The regulation of the disposal of hazardous wastes, which includes hospital wastes of the kind to which the honourable senator refers, is the responsibility of the States and Territories and not of the Commonwealth. As I understand the situation, the New South Wales Government, however, does have this issue under investigation now. I know that Mr Gibson has requested the Greiner Government to hold a royal commission. I am not aware, though, of whether the New South Wales Government has responded.

The New South Wales Government has also set up a committee of local members, which includes Mr Gibson, to look at the issue. I understand that an inspection has taken place, although no report has yet come back. When I get further information on the outcome of the review, I will let the honourable senator know.

In so far as the disposal of hazardous and toxic wastes generally is concerned, the Commonwealth has for the past couple of years, along with the New South Wales and Victorian governments, had a task force in operation to look at the siting of Australia's first high temperature incinerator actually to deal with the problem. Sydney is one city sitting on a number of environmental time bombs of this kind. As I understand it from my last inquiry, there are something like 10,000 barrels of polychlorinated biphenyls being stored in Sydney. Any accident involving those barrels could create a disaster of enormous dimension. That is a matter that will have to be dealt with by a high temperature incinerator.

The Commonwealth and the New South Wales governments will have to keep this issue of hazardous and toxic wastes under constant review. It is something that has been ignored in Australia forever and our society cannot afford to ignore it a day longer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the Governor-General's Speech last week which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's policies outlined in the 1987 Defence White Paper will continue to guide the development of Australia's defence capabilities . . .

Does the Government remain committed to the projections for defence spending-that is, around 2.6 to 2.7 per cent of gross domestic product-identified in the White Paper even though it has failed to achieve such a level of spending in any year since 1987? Will the Government confirm that it will be undertaking a major strategic and force structure review since many strategic assumptions of the White Paper have been overtaken and since defence spending is to be cut by this Government in the next Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some modifications to the defence budget to take account of economic circumstances. At the moment the defence budget for the next year has a guaranteed one per cent real growth rather than 2 per cent as envisaged some months ago in the Forward Estimates. In relation to the second question, I have not made a final decision as to whether to have a force structure review. If I do decide on that, Senator, I think you can assume that an announcement will be imminent-in the next new weeks.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, do we take it that the recent comments of Vice-Admiral Hudson were wrong when he foreshadowed that this review was likely to take place?

—You would be well aware, Mr President, that the most recent book on military history refers to the Navy as `first in'. This is probably another instance of that: the Navy has shown commendable initiative in perhaps announcing the decision ahead of my decision on this matter. Nevertheless, I encourage the Defence Force chiefs to be as publicly accessible as possible. Sometimes they get grilled by journalists and, being men of honour, they are not quite as slippery as us and a few things spill out. I do not take offence at that in any way because I think it is very important to have openness in this area. But it is my decision to make, and I will be the one who makes it, not one of the Defence Force chiefs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIA: MANUFACTURE OF ROCKET FUEL AND MOTORS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. My question concerns the proposed construction of a facility to make rocket fuel and rocket motors at Elizabeth in South Australia. Has the decision been taken to proceed with this facility? Is a plan of the exact site available to nearby residents? What type or types of fuel will be manufactured? Will this fuel be stored on site, and if so, how much? Is it intended that the rocket motors be used for military and/or civil use? If military, will Australia be supplying either fuel or motors to foreign powers? Will the rockets be capable of carrying nuclear warheads? Would it be possible for me to visit the site?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I ask you to direct that that is an abuse of Question Time. It could not possibly be within the province of the Minister to answer that question unless he has had advance notice, in which case it defeats the whole purpose of the exercise; otherwise, it is simply a method of making a speech in circumstances which are available in many other forums.
—Order! There is no point of order. Whether the Senator has given the Minister notice or not, it is not for me to make a decision. It is a very long question, Senator Coulter

—I am about to ask the final part. Is Australia now conforming with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) principles which set down recommended quantity/distance requirements in relation to the storage of ammunition and explosives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —By an enormous coincidence, Mr President, I did manage to peruse this question earlier in the day. If Senator Coulter wanted a sensible answer on these matters, it would have been very crass of him not to give at least a minor preview, and I appreciate that.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the first question is yes. As to question two: it is not the normal practice for the company-and I must interpose here that we are talking about Australian Defence Industries and not the Department of Defence-to provide detailed plans for the general public. However, the Elizabeth City Council has been provided with detailed briefs and has visited the site as recently as 10 May. Councillors and council staff were given every opportunity to examine the site and ask detailed questions.

Question three: The types of fuel to be manufactured at the new facility will be cast composite and cast double based solid propellant rocket motors. Question four: Fuel will be stored at the site. It will be stored in solid state as cast motors. It is not possible to discuss in a public forum the quantity of these materials which will be stored but quantities will be small and will comply with NATO safety principles. The Department monitors conformity to those principles.
Question five: Yes, it will have a military use. Question six: Yes, it will be exported. Question seven: No, it will not have a role to play in nuclear warheads.

Question eight: Senator Coulter seeks an invitation. I now extend that invitation. He will be very welcome to visit the site at any time. I ask him to give us a day's notice so that people will be expecting him.

Finally Senator Coulter asked about the NATO safety standards. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation's Salisbury site conforms fully with the NATO safety principles. To expand on that, rather than take a lot of time in Question Time, I might write to Senator Coulter on the exact safety measures being used and how they will be complied with. It would take too long at Question Time to go into that detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It would appear that the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), which is responsible for the administration of Medicare, and now the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, keeps Medicare information on-line for two years and has stored off-line all Medicare information since the inception of Medicare. I understand that this information may have some use in the long term to provide epidemiological information. However, I ask the Minister: Is it Government policy that this information be stored in a way that individuals and details of their treatment as indicated by item numbers can be identified indefinitely?

—There was a considerable discussion on this matter in a Senate Estimates committee last night and I think there was some elucidation of the fact that, whilst this material is held by the Health Insurance Commission, in fact it is held under a number which is not equivalent to the Medicare number. So it is true that that connection could be made by a clerk, I guess, in the HIC. I am quite convinced that the Government would be concerned that all privacy safeguards that are necessary are adhered to. I will bring Senator Patterson's concern to the attention of the Minister and seek a further response if he wishes to add anything.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister see any problems with privacy which could arise given that the data is stored in this form? If so, will the Government do something about eradicating the ability to identify individuals indefinitely?

—I believe that in the first part of her question Senator Patterson recognises that there is some virtue in keeping the substantive part of these records for epidemiological surveys. However, in so far as individuals might be identified, I have indicated that there is a real privacy concern and I will certainly bring that to the attention of the Minister.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to a media report regarding research undertaken by the University of South Sydney which claims that monosodium glutamate is no real danger to the health of non-asthmatics and that not enough information is available to clearly show it poses any danger to asthmatics? I ask the Minister: Has he or his Department been able to test the validity of the claim made in the report? If not, will the Minister undertake to have the report assessed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have something in the brief of the Minister for Community Services and Health. I assume that Senator Jones is referring to a paper entitled MSG: A balanced perspective presented at the recent Australian Institute of Food Science and Technology annual convention by Dr Tarasoff of the University of Western Sydney. I understand that the paper reviews the results of ingestion of monosodium glutamate under controlled laboratory conditions in 41 healthy subjects using well accepted research techniques. The results show monosodium glutamate by itself in doses three to four times that normally ingested in a typical Chinese meal caused symptoms in some subjects. The symptoms included headaches, light-headedness, stiffness and tightness, tingling, warmth and burning and, finally, weakness of limbs. Many of the symptoms usually attributed to the Chinese restaurant syndrome, including asthma, were not found in this sample group. The majority of symptoms were described as mild and lasted from 10 to 60 minutes after onset.

ANSWER.PARA: This paper is a useful contribution to the store of knowledge on the effects of monosodium glutamate, although caution must be exercised because of the relatively small sample size. The study shows that symptoms, although mild, do occur and reinforces the need for adequate labelling of products as specified in the National Health and Medical Research Council's food standards code so that those persons who believe they are affected are aware of the presence of monosodium glutamate.

I believe that in the case of packaged food in Australia an indication of the presence of monosodium glutamate-I think by reference to a number-is required. In relation to unpackaged food there is no such requirement. I will take Senator Jones's concern in this matter into my discussions with those concerned with my portfolio interests as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to see whether that provision of information in relation to unpackaged food might be made available so that people can make an informed choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In light of the Deputy Prime Minister's reprimand for your lack of performance on tariff reform, could the Minister explain whether his inability to match the Deputy Prime Minister's ambition is due to increased labour costs for industry of up to 22 per cent in the form of increased superannuation tax, a 38-hour week, training levies and second tier wage increases for productivity increases? Does the Minister agree that it would be difficult to speed up reduced tariff protection until there is significant labour market reform and increased productivity?

—The first part of the question goes to issues of macro-economic policy in respect of which I have been a participant in Cabinet and have no disagreement with the Treasurer or anybody else. Over the last year or so I have answered numerous questions here about those issues-for example, relating to wages policy. I certainly do not retract anything I have said in those answers over that period. Senator Boswell in the second part of his question asked me whether there was a need for a substantial program of reform which would alleviate burdens on industry in one way or another and in the context of which tariff reform could take place. Yes, I agree with that. It was announced by the Government prior to the election and anything that has since been said about it is consistent with that pre-selection announcement.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to a report in the West Australian of last week concerning the Government's proposed training levy. In the article the claim is made that the levy will hurt Western Australian businesses more than businesses in the eastern States in that a higher proportion of small businesses will have to pay the levy due to factors which are unique to the State. Are these claims correct? How does the Government plan to monitor the effect of the levy to ensure that the impact is fair and equitable and that special local factors such as those claimed are given full consideration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset it should be stated that the Government's initiative in this area of a training guarantee is based on a recognition of and very strong commitment to understanding that businesses in all States need to undertake quality training. They need to do so to realise two objectives, both for the businesses involved and for the economy in general. Those objectives, of course, are to improve productivity and enhance competitiveness, thus ensuring that businesses compete successfully in what is a growing competitive market.

ANSWER.PARA: The report from Western Australia is one that is of interest. It should be noted, for instance, that Western Australia is behind in terms of the amount of money expended on training at the moment. A recent Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) training expenditure survey found that average expenditure on formal training in Western Australia was 1.6 per cent of gross wages and salaries, compared with the Australia-wide average of 2.2 per cent. So there is already a very substantial difference in terms of expenditure. It should also be noted that amongst employers reporting some formal training, average expenditure was 2.1 per cent, compared with the nationwide average of 2.9 per cent. As I say, there is already some ground to be made up in Western Australia. There are a couple of reasons why there is that sort of discrepancy. The survey indicated that on average Western Australian employers who provide training provide fewer hours of training per employee than the national average. They provide 5.9 hours compared with the national average of 7.9.

The other reason for this discrepancy is that a higher proportion of firms in Western Australia-about 83 per cent compared with 78 per cent for the whole of Australia-spend absolutely nothing on formal training. It has been maintained by Mr Maynard that Western Australian businesses have a different case. The 1987 ABS data show that the proportion of enterprises in Western Australia which employ fewer than 10 people is approximately the same as it is in other States-about 90 per cent. That is the benchmark which will be applied as to which enterprises are within the ambit of the training guarantee and which are not. So we have the same proportion of enterprises operating nationwide.

Mr Maynard also makes the point that a higher proportion of small businesses in Western Australia will have to pay the levy. In response to that, it should be acknowledged that those firms which are covered by the training guarantee will have to increase expenditure on training, rather than pay the levy. That is a direct objective of the Government in this area. The third point that Mr Maynard makes is that this structured training does not suit the nature of Western Australian industries. In response to that, Senator Beahan and other honourable senators should note that all industries will benefit from improving the quality of training they offer, including structured on the job training.

The role given to industry training agencies will provide an increased opportunity and avenue for the industries training committees and industry associations to develop appropriate structured training arrangements for their industries. The last part of Senator Beahan's question refers to monitoring the training guarantee. In that respect, the Government will use the training expenditure survey to monitor the effect of the training guarantee on expenditure on training at both state and industry level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade confirm that when the Australian Embassy in Addis Ababa was closed in December 1987 the Department management here in Canberra ordered that all unclassified records of the Embassy be carried `safe hand' by diplomatic courier back to Australia? Can the Minister confirm that this exercise cost the Australian taxpayer $26,000 in air freight? Can the Minister confirm that the documents couriered back to Australia related to car pool operational records, repair dockets for Embassy toilets and routine accounts? Can the Minister further confirm that all these documents were destroyed within one week of their return to Australia?

—I do not know how I missed that, but back in 1988 I was not following the closure of our Embassy in Ethiopia or the transfer of material at that stage. I am sure that a few inquiries can be made to find out whether the allegations made by Senator Bishop in fact transpired. I will have inquiries made as to what paperwork was brought back to Australia, the cost of that exercise and how the documents were disposed of.
—The problem is that you do treat all this as inconsequential. It is taxpayers' money.

—That is the second lonely voice from way up there that we have heard in the last two minutes. One good thing about Senator Bishop is that she will prove something that I have always wanted to know: Does suet pudding rise twice?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY: REVIEW OF AUSTRALIA'S ENERGY POLICY AND PROGRAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the International Energy Agency (IEA) recently reported on its regular review of Australia's energy policy and programs? What were the findings, and how does the Government intend to deal with its recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Energy Agency, which is a subagency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), did conduct its periodic inspection of Australia's energy policy and programs and reported its findings on 3 May this year. Overall, the thrust and direction of the report is in line with the Government's energy policies. The report is complimentary of the Federal Government's actions over the last three years to increase competitiveness and efficiency of our energy industries through its involvement in the deregulation of the oil markets, through introducing a flexible tax regime, such as the resource rent tax, and through the rationalisation of the coal industry.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, the report gives a big tick to the Government's micro-economic reform program as achieved thus far and endorses our approach for waterfront and coastal shipping reform which is the responsibility of Senator Collins. It also speaks complimentarily of our deregulation of the local liquefied petroleum gas market.

The report does, however, raise a number of issues and concerns in relation to the current energy policy. Several of them are the perennial issues that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development typically raises, and many are related to the fact that we are a federation of States and in that sense have a split approach, given that most of the domestic electricity generation is carried by the States.

Some of the issues which were raised under the heading of criticisms included the rationalisation of tax and non-tax charges; the integration of State gas and electricity systems; emphasis on energy conservation and substitution; and the promotion of exploration and development through the appropriate taxation measures. Many of those things will be addressed by the Industry Commission inquiry dealing with those matters; and I think the Treasurer has already announced that.

One of the areas of criticism is the consistent area of international objective criticism of Australia-that is, where the State governments, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland under its old guise, loaded rail freight costs as an extra tax surcharge and as a hidden tax on exports. The OECD has singled that out for criticism. I understand that Mr Kerin and Mr Griffiths, the two responsible Ministers, have referred the IEA's report to the next meeting of State Ministers and they intend to take up those matters in that context. They believe that is important, given the importance of the energy and environment debate, particularly the impact on the greenhouse effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind the Minister that the taxation zone rebates currently in existence have applied since the 1984-85 financial year. Is the Minister aware that although several of the related dependant rebates were increased for the 1989-90 financial year, and all are now indexed annually, no provisions were made in the 1989-90 Federal Budget for an increase in zone allowance? As the aim of the zone rebates is to provide some relief to taxpayers for disabilities arising from isolation and higher living costs and to provide a degree of tax equity and incentive for people to work in remote areas, what action has the Government taken, or will it take, to reverse the diminished value of the zone allowance?

—I am familiar with some of the details of the honourable senator's question, but I am not familiar with the precise consideration that has been given by the Government to this issue at this time. I undertake to provide the honourable senator with an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Did the Treasurer write to the Minister early in 1989 advocating an early review of the passenger vehicle industry by the Industry Commission? Did the Minister reject this suggestion and, if so, on what grounds? Is it not normal practice for such industry reviews to be undertaken by the Industry Commission? If so, why did the Minister ask Cabinet last week to bring forward the review of the industry without reference to the Industry Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1988 the Government made a very substantial review of the motor vehicle industry without reference to the Industry Commission, as I said yesterday in the Senate. In 1988 we abolished quotas on the industry and announced a considerable reduction in tariffs. I would like to say that that was a unanimous decision of the Government in 1988. In 1989 the Treasurer wrote to me seeking an early review of the passenger motor vehicle industry. That, as I understand it, was on the basis of discussions with the chief executives of two companies in the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Subsequently I was told by those two executives and other executives of the industry that they had changed their minds about having an early review and I communicated that information to the Treasurer. As a result, no early review took place.

In the context of the present Government, as I said in answer to questions yesterday, there were two ways of reviewing the motor vehicle industry. One way was for the Government to do exactly what it did in 1988 without any criticism from within the Government or from outside. There was no criticism from the Opposition parties or anybody else. What we did in 1988 was done without reference to the Industries Assistance Commission. On this occasion we could have done two things. We could have conducted a quick review without reference to the Industry Commission or we could have had an Industry Commission review. I brought forward a document which put options before the Cabinet and those options were both included.

As I said yesterday, my concern was that the matter should be dealt with quickly-now-because the industry has been concerned about its investment plans and it wants it dealt with quickly. If the Government had dealt with it, using the Automotive Industry Authority and the Department, it could have done so very quickly. But when the Government decided that the Industry Commission could do a quick review-that is, by 31 December this year; rather than a review of the type we are used to in this Parliament, of 12 or 18 months-I was delighted with that piece of information. The Commission now has a reference before it, the terms of which were settled and agreed between the Treasurer and me. That review will start now and will be completed by 31 December. That is very pleasing as far as I am concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. As I understood it, he said that the decision to review the matter without reference to the Industry Commission was without criticism within and without the Government. In the light of that answer, why did the Treasurer say publicly yesterday that the Minister's approach to Cabinet last week in terms of reviewing the industry without reference to the Commission was `unacceptable'?

—Senator Short is confusing two issues. I do not blame him for that. I said that the 1988 decision to deal with the motor vehicle industry in terms of quotas and tariffs without reference to the Industries Assistance Commission was a decision which attracted no criticism from within or without the Government at that time. That was in 1988. That decision, which was agreed upon within the Government, was thought to be a very good one. All members of the Government in 1988 agreed to it.
—All members?

—All members of the Government, I said. In relation to the recent decision to refer the matter to the Industry Commission, I answered that question in my original answer. I said that I put options to the Government about how the matter might be dealt with. My concern was that it should be dealt with quickly. I thought that probably the quickest way of dealing with it was the way in which we did it in 1988.
—Which the Treasurer now finds unacceptable?
—Yes.
—Why?
—Perhaps you should ask me that question next Question Time and I will answer in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer.
—I did.

—No, he did not. He asked me as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. But, in so far as the decision of the Government was concerned in respect of this reference to the Industry Commission, I am not unhappy with it. Again, nobody is unhappy with it. The fact that that can be done by the Industry Commission in six months is a very good thing and I applaud that course.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1989-90

In Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1989-90, appropriations totalling $9.7 million additional to those made in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1989-90 are sought for recurrent expenditures of the Parliamentary Departments. The increase sought relates primarily to essential and unavoidable costs associated with the operation of Parliament House. In addition, an increase of $0.1 million is sought in the Advance to the President. This increase would bring the amount of the Advance up to $0.3 million, in line with the Advance to the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1989-90

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1989-90, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the Additional Estimates for 1989-90.

In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditure additional to the Appropriations made for 1989-90 under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

Although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet the impact of the National Wage Case decision.

Of the additional appropriations in the three Additional Estimates Bills totalling $1,018.0 million, $588.8 million is sought in Appropriation Bill No 3, $419.5 million in Appropriation Bill No 4 and $9.8 million in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill No 2.

These amounts are offset, in part, by savings in the Appropriation made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1989-90 reflecting the Government's continued determination to improve the efficiency of ongoing programs. These savings, amounting to $352.9 million, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document, ``Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations'', which has been distributed to Members. In addition, a clause which has the effect of reducing by $399,000 an appropriation for the bounty under the Bounty (Ship Repair) Act 1986 made by Appropriation Act (No 1) is included in Appropriation Bill (No 3).

After allowance for this reduction and the prospective savings, the appropriations now sought represent a net increase of $664.7 million in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. As a proportion of total estimated Outlays-encompassing both Annual and Standing Appropriations-this increase amounts to 0.8 per cent.

I now outline some of the main areas for which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No 3) 1989-90 to meet expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

$110 million, or an increase of 1.3%, is included for increased running costs, of which $80 million is included to cover the costs of the first instalment of the National Wage Case decisions, while the $30 million for administrative and operational expenses is associated mostly with transfers from salaries and various minor new policy initiatives.
Gross additional estimates of $240.0 million are sought for the Defence Portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No 3).
The gross figures include:
$52.6 million for Running Costs, reflecting the impact of the first instalment of the National Wage Case decisions and increases in certain allowances for Defence Personnel and civilians;
$92.7 million which largely reflects adjustment for price movements and variations in progress on a number of projects, including payments for ANZAC Ships;
$40.1 million for costs associated with the establishment of Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd and Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd;
$27.5 million for Defence Facilities attributable to price increases and greater activity levels; and
$25.6 million for Defence Housing, reflecting interest bearing loan capital and increases in market rents to be paid by Defence to the Defence Housing Authority.

Taking account of all transactions contributing to the Defence function, including offsets provided from increased Revenues and a reduction in the provision for contingent salary and related increases, total Defence Outlays are estimated to increase by $126 million.

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) also provides $30 million for the Australian Trade Commission to meet eligible grants under the Export Market Development Grant Scheme. The additional funds are estimated to be sufficient to enable settlement of all grants that are expected to be processed and hence payable by 30 June.
In addition, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) provides:
$23.5 million to assist in the recovery of the tourism industry following the pilots' dispute;
$60.1 million for the increased demand for non-departmental care for veterans and the corresponding flow-on costs in Veterans' Medical Services; and
$6.0 million for a bounty on sensitised film production.
These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget as well as requirements of an on-going nature.
The principal factors underlying the requirements include certain unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1989-90

In Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1989-90, appropriations totalling $419.5 million-additional to those made by Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1989-90-are sought for capital works and services, payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory, advances and loans and for other services. The proposed appropriations are needed to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures for which provision was not made in that Act.

The additional appropriations are sought to meet certain cost and price increases which have occurred since the budget, together with other requirements to be met this financial year. Areas where significant increases are sought over amounts provided in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 are the provision of:
$7.8 million, mainly payments to the States, to assist in the recovery of the tourist industry;
$70 million for payments to the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority for charges waived under the Agreement with the airlines resulting from the pilots' industrial action;
$13.2 million for the establishment of a trust fund to provide financial assistance to people with medically acquired HIV;
$30 million as an injection of equity capital for Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd and an additional $20 million advance to facilitate acquisition of a 99 year lease of Avalon Airfield;
$75 million for a capital injection to AUSSAT Pty Ltd;

$25 million for natural disaster relief and restoration including damage by the Newcastle earthquake and provision for bushfires and floods in the first two months of 1990. The bulk of the Commonwealth's payments to the States for assistance in respect of the recent floods in New South Wales and Queensland is expected to be paid in 1990-91.
$10 million for the Commonwealth/Tasmania Forest Industry Strategy; and
$15.6 million for Australia's contribution to settlement of outstanding debts of the International Tin Council.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990-91

This Bill seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing requirements of the Parliamentary Departments during the period 1 July 1990 to 30 November 1990. They total some $47.6 million which is $1.3 million, or 2.9 per cent, greater than the amount provided for in the supply period 1989-90.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1990-91

This Bill, together with its companion bills, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing services of the Government during the period 1 July 1990 to 30 November 1990, by which date it is expected that the appropriation Bills, which will form part of the Budget for 1990-91, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No 1) seeks appropriations totalling $10,689 million for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $742 million, or about 7.5 per cent, greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No 1) 1989-90.
A significant part of the increase reflects commitments which have been approved by the Government, price and cost increases and exchange rate variations.

As has been the case in recent years, the running cost appropriations of Departments have been adjusted to include the salaries of Departmental Secretaries and other relevant Office Holders which were previously paid from Special Appropriations.

I wish to emphasise that this Bill seeks interim provision only in respect of approved ongoing policies of the Government. It does not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1990-91 Budget context for which provision will be sought in the Appropriation Bills.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY BILL (No 2) 1990-91

This Bill seeks interim appropriations, totalling some $2,940 million, for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory and certain other services for the period 1 July 1990 to 30 November 1990.
The amount sought is $73 million, or about 2.4 per cent, less than that provided in the Supply Act (No 2) 1989-90.
Certain new provisions in respect of which Government decisions have been taken have been separately itemised in the Bill in accordance with convention.
As indicated with respect to the Supply Bill No 1, the provisions in this Bill do not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1990-91 Budget context.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
